reviewText:
Well, the main redeeming qualities of LP1 and LP2 were the mechs for me.  In LP3, they've made it mostly a means to travel from point to point, with some melee fighting abilities.  Most the big battles you end up doing on foot, with your standard load out of guns. The music for the game is very well done, and a neat component with the rig blaring out the music from earth.  The graphics are very nice, and the vistas are sometimes breath taking.  The UI is well done, and the controls aren't too bad.  Some of their choices for what does what don't make alot of sense, since almost everything they could have tied to a simple 'use' key intead of making every different action type a different key.

I won't be finishing the game.  Between the no real mech play, the boredom of repetive tasks and respawn, and the arena fights... I just can't do it.

reviewText:
+Summary at End+

This game is great, I almost feel bad I didn't get into it at the tutorial and almost skipped it.

Lost Planet 3 is its own beast in the series and differs greatly from the others, its more character and story driven and got rid of the arcade style missions (no more end of level scoring) and adds sort of a hybrid open world as well.

Note: No multiplayer review.

The audio and visuals are very slick and for being an ice planet they keep everything looking great considering the limited palette choice. You can even add your own radio station, so to say, while using your rig (mech) however the times you can use the radio are limited and you'll often find it disabled while doing missions. Nothing blends either so you won't really have any problem finding what you need and they've included a breadcrumb system you can bring up if you're unsure where to go (which you do tend to use often mainly when going to a mission location) which is always nice to have and its use is optional during most points of the game.

Gunplay is simple, turning is more fluid and it doesn't require buttons for moving 90 degrees at a time like its predecessors, but I do have one complaint, the default controller scene is terrible for keyboard and mouse. If I'm using the mouse to look and the AWDS keys to move WHY IS 'P' THE USE KEY! It doesn't make any sense, I just used a controller which made sense with its default scheme. They added cover to the game as well but on normal difficulty I only used it during the last stage so in most playthroughs its a forgettable mechanic. The AI isn't too compelling either but you can still die if you're careless.

Actually, there really isn't a threat during the game but it doesn't keep things from being tense.

You  don't have small mechs this time around, instead you have the first generation rigs" which are big lumbering robots and for story reasons don't have weapons. So you'll be relying on melee combat while using your rig which is surprisingly satisfying. However
date: again you aren't really in danger most cases as even if your rig is... shut down? It will heal itself over time and you can usually be back in it at full health in little time.\n\nSo
recommended: it's fun but bear in mind that if isn't the most challenging game you'll find.\n\nWhich is fine

reviewText:
Nicholas (Cage)*(Tom) Hanks is the protagonist.

You cannot unsee this.

While I don't think it should at all be called a sequel of the series, since it's so wildly different, it does share some similarities in name and in lore. It's an OK game, but it's a shootoff, not what one should consider an official installment.

I can appreciate the work that the team put into developing it, and the boss-fights were at least well-thought-out. I had very low expectations going into it, but have since been pleasantly surprised.

Do not go in expecting any similarities, other than superficial similarities to Lost Planet.

The gunplay is mostly decent, the enemy design is decent, but the weapons are somewhat bland, and it has lost any sense of outlandish caricatures of robotic weaponry that the previous games had. It is a cover shooter and a robot beat-em-up with some additional collection features.

The game does have its good points, though.
-Attention to detail
-Characters (other than the main character)
-A sense of... coldness
-Boss fights are engaging and well-designed for the team's level of development experience
-Enemy design means you have to engage each one differently
-RIG Combat is actually pretty fun (when you do fight against large Akrid)

The bad parts, however, plunge the game into mediocrity
-Pacing in combat sections isn't very-well thought out for some instances
-The game feels like a cover shooter that borrows many elements from other games without making them its own
-The upgrade system for the weapons is shallow and wasn't explored deeply enough by the development team
-It's not really Lost Planet other than names and lore
-Some of the weapons (esp. the Pulse Rifle) feel clunky.
-Some explorational/collection mechanics aren't explained very well

I cannot recommend this game, however, due to how much of an offshoot it is from its predecessors, quirky and zany as they may have been. It's a completely different game and doesn't really come into its own. Plus, a lack of co-operative play is a big no-no since MP was DOA.

reviewText: This game can get very repetitive and the rig battles take a lot of the enjoyment out of the gameplay. Completing missions often involves following guided points to a location, completing the objective, and then walking all the way back to base for the next mission. Returning back can take as much as 10-15 minutes sometimes. Getting fast travel at base helps this some, but does not completely deal with this problem. Combat is farily repetitive and enemies are rarely unique in form or attacks. Once a boss encounter occurs you often fight the same boss 2-4 times in a row to complete the objective. Rig battles consist of your character moving around in a mech without any guns. You claw, punch and drill enemies to kill them. The problem lies in the slowness of the mech unit with its attacks. Often times an enemy can get in 2 or 3 attacks before you can effectively get in a single blow. These battles often consist of QTE (quick time events) to beat the enemy which means you can't just pummel the enemy into submission despite having the tools to do so; it requires a certain repeatable pattern for each enemy type. I often found it easier to get out of the mech and fight on foot. I got this game for $0.25 as part of a bundle, but I wouldn't recommend it because it is too repetitive to get enjoyment out of.

reviewText: 9/10\n\nOnly reason I'm not giving it a 10 is because of the lack of replayability in the campaign. Over all, it has great graphics, a better storyline compared to LP 2, and a lot of nail biting action. Some bugs are present, but none that I noticed that were game breaking. I have played the first and the second Lost Planet games, and this one would have to take the cake as far as freedom to explore. Hopefully this isn't the end of the series, as there is still a lot the developers could do. If you liked the first two, just realise this isn't going to be the same, and you'll be fine. :)

reviewText:
After reconsidering giving this game another go ( I had a very frustratiing time with getting the game to not crash every time it loaded up ) I have finally been able to put my 25 dollars on this game to use. The graphics are stellar, the environment isn't very much like the other LPs but it is a welcome change for me. Mechs are fun, however I did enjoy the mech design from LP1 the most. Gunplay is easy to get used to, and much more makes this game a good buy! I've had my problems with this game to where I've spent a solid hour deleting, redownloading, verifying all the files that may or may not make it crash. I still have to play in windowed mode, which is not what I prefer but It's really not that big of a deal. I just started playing and I looked over at the clock and an hour and a half flew by in an instant. Personally, I think this game is worth the money. Get it on sale now though. Steam's Summer Sale has it at around 12 bucks so it's the best time right now! If you are reading this after, still spend the money on it! Fantastic game! PLEASE READ BELOW FOR CONS


*NOTICE*:: In the beggining of my experience with this I had A LOT of problems with crashing. There were fixes online that helped and were detailed enough so someone that is not software gifted like myself could find it. I did run into crashing later in the game and there was no solution for it. It was on the first level but still. ALSO, my PC is not the best one ever. I have problems with it's stability. So, what I'm trying to say is that some problems may be on me. Research beyond Steam Reviews for the best opinion possible. REMEMBER!!! I have had problems with this port and still have problems! They are minor, like how I have to play in windowed mode, but otherwise, I see no reason not to buy this phenomenal game!

reviewText: I guess I need to preface this review by stating that I have not played the first two games in this series.  I've heard that this game is very different from its predecessors but that should not take away that this is a very fun game to play.  The environment is great, the characters are believable, and there's plenty of action, especially if you're into button mashing.   The game play itself feels the weakest, as if they didn't do a particularly good job of making this game keyboard/mouse friendly.   However, as long as you can let that go, this game is very enjoyable.

reviewText:
IF YOU LIKED LOST PLANET 1, YOU WILL PROBABLY LOVE THIS ONE ALSO BUT...
We have again a good game powered by Unreal Engine and, that means HUGE structures, scenarios. Everything very realistic and impressive BUT... the Akrids (the monsters) look like exactly the same as with LP1 and, that's awfull.
The introductory sequences are like to be watching a good sci-fi film and, it set your expectatives higher than the game delivers at the end.
Excesive Keys, that could be resumed in way less keys (multi-functional, depending on context), make the actions more complex than needed.
Reaction time between you press a key and the character does the action is a tad high and, this delay is a mess when fighting against some of the Akrids and, very specially when you are surrounded of lots of them.
I cannot understand why a game that has been HIGHLY enhanced respect of scenarios and detailed graphics, leaved the combat system and character's movements quite well the same as in LP1.
I mean, why the character has no possibility to jump over obstactles, why cannot crouch, why cannot reach other high spots but only those that the engine highlights?.
Why the Akrids seem so out-of-dated compared with the rest of E.D.E.N. III world?.

reviewText:
game is bugged so far spent hours trying to get around a documented bink problem that is years old and unfixed

well after struggling through the disorganized pinned thread on the problem I finally figured out a process (based on guesswork, trial and error) to get this to work for me.

Just download the HD videos and verify your game files once the download is complete & some files may need to be redownloaded then the bink crash stops.  Somewhere along the way I downloaded a different version of bink32.dll (see the thread) but I'm not sure what version exactly because there are about 10 of them and I can't remember so you'll have to try all of them hahaha.   Which ultimately may not be necessary.

So where do you get the hd videos well I'll throw you a bone in the DLC section for this game.

So I played the intro about 20 times trying to figure out how to stop this crashing and annoyingly the autosave (only) saves at a point where you have to shoot a bunch of akrid before a cutscene.

The other annoying thing  is that it takes 1 minute 25 seconds to get through the splash screens alone and they can't be skipped.  You have to make a short cut with some parameter that I'm going to have to look up again.

Once you get through all that the game seems to be a relatively straightforward 'hold down your left mouse button and it will complete from start to finish' fps.  It was so worth the hassle.

reviewText: Great story with excellent voice-acting that makes it that much more relatable, really charming story and characters with a sly sense of humor. reviewText:
You're working as Jim from earth to E.D.N III to get money for his family down there.

Why did i use the word working instread of playing ?
because it is how it feels when you play the game you're not playing but working.

As you can expect from a guy who has a RIG (giant mech) you'll ... dig big holes and protect it while it does... sounds great right ?

So, yes, the gameplay is really meh, it's almost the same all the time you're going there, plant your rig or power something up and kill waves and waves of akrids then go back to mainbase, buy some upgrade, and so on.

Then, why did i keep playing through the whole game ? because of the story : it takes place far before the first Lost Planet and it's really well written and even if it's not the biggest plot ever, it does the job nice enough to keep you in the game 'till the end (around 10 hours, depends if you're doing side quest that are as boring as the main gameplay).

To sum up, it's hard to recommend it but it's also hard to say it's a bad game. Sure, the gameplay itself is pretty meh but was it on purpose to serve the story until the end to truly understand how it comes to all this ?
maybe, maybe not, i'm not sure and even if it is, it's still kind of a weird choice.

Anyway, pick at low price like i did if you want a great story and learn more about lost planet background otherwise do not pick this up.

reviewText:
There are a lot of things this game is but I'll tell you one thing this game isn't, a Lost Planet game. It is nothing like its predecessors, the gameplay is almost entirely different.

Improvements:
- Graphics are gorgeous and well optimized
- Character dialogue isn't flat and confusing, doesn't feel like I'm hearing a half-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• translation of a game that was written in Japanese in the first place.
- The Rig feels pretty sweet I'll admit

Downgrades:
- Much more restrictive third person camera
- Much more restrictive movement
- Much more restrictive environments
- Less free-flow combat and open areas that let you tackle objectives in whatever way you see fit
- QTE's and I don't mean hammering B to set up the T-Posts either
- T-Eng now has no gameplay purpose past purchasing upgrades, it's now used in the in-game shop to buy upgrades and weapons
- The Rig is in FIRST FREAKING PERSON OH GOD WHY

This game has everything you could ever want from an action game: Lots of challenging enemies, upgradable guns, boss fights, an upgradable mech (Stomping xenos in a huuge mech? Hell yeah!) and a good level design with some free style exploration included.

For those of you, all that is not enough reason to buy, the story is also very good and the main character is actually very human and believable. As are all other chracters in this game. Through some short videoclips you learn about the hopes, dreams and habits of Jim Peyton as he scrambles to survive.

You like action? You love a good story with horror elements? You want a big, stompy mech?

BUY this game!

reviewText: The game begins with a crash landing on an ice plan several years in the future. You, a lone mercenary, are equipped with a basic weapon, survival suit, & bad controls. The opening to the game is extremely reminiscent of Dead Space 3, in fact, several parts of the game are pretty close. That said, there are some key differences between the two. In Dead Space, you get to make your own guns & upgrade them freely, in lost planet, theres a store where you buy weapons & a few upgrades for them such as scopes & extened magazines. In Dead Space, everything was compact, linear, & required little back tracking, in Lost world, you have a base of operation where you will return to after every sortie & which you can wander out of freely to do side mission. This gives it a sort of open world feel, but instead of it feeling like you can wander freely around, it feels like you have to go out for hours at a time since it takes so long to march back to base in either your boots or your giant mech that moves at about 3 mph. Combat is rigid at best, you are constantly swarmed by either waves upon waves of small weak enemies, or huge boss monsters that have very repettative patterns. Another huge difference between Dead space & this game is that Dead Space is a survival horror. You have a set health bar which you have to scavence to replenish, ammunition can be scarce depending what dificulty you play. In Lost Planet, you have regenerating health  & ammo is avaliable around every corner, or you can rely on your pistol which pulls infinite ammo from space & time. In other words, this game is extremley easy, even though I played through it on normal diffiulty. All in all, you have better uses for your money, but if you're just bored, this can be a c+ game

reviewText:
The game, although pretty, tries exceedingly hard to be something it isn't.

It's excessively buggy, unintuitive, whoever designed the default controls was a complete idiot.
Such bugs include the explosive crossbow gun occasionally exploding some mysterious 4th bolt directly on top of you when looking through the scope. Or not being able to winch to a point unless you find some stupid, tiny little point to stand on.

The parts of the game that try to be horror are excessively unpleasant, rather then be scary, they provide nothing but frustration, as the enemies are simple, small things that die easily, but are always there and never startling, despite trying to be.

One particular moment that angered me was in a horror segment, I repaired a small turret, which was placed to help me defend whilst a door opens. The turret proceeded to shoot and kill ONE enemy, before spending the rest of the attack looking at different enemies, but not actually firing at them.

It also has a stupid amount of walking from place to place, and heaps of back tracking.

All in all, the game is a travesty, if you were after a Lost Planet game, you came to the wrong place.

reviewText: Lost Planet 3 tells the story of Jim Peyton, a blue collar family man from Earth, sent to a remote colony on planet E.D.N. III, 50 years after the events of the first game.  As the story unfolds, Jim learns that mega-corp NEVEC has been up to no good, and that he is embroiled in a conspiracy a generation in the making.  The art, sound and voice direction in this game are truly top notch not only making the story line unfold like a feature length film, but giving nuance and style to the gameplay itself.  In addition to a third person shooter, Jim can take control a utility mech, giving the player some compelling puzzle solving and innovative combat along the way.  The game supports Steam Trading Cards, Widescreen modes as well as the Xbox controller, but unfortunately is lacking any Steam Achievements.  Barring that one minor flaw however, Lost Planet 3 is truly a game not to be missed by even casual fans of the sci-fi genre.  I highly recommend this game to almost anyone.

reviewText:
No... Just no... This game is truly horrible compared to the previous titles.
Combat is boring and the traveling is boring.
The mech is there only to give you means of travel, you get a minimap and proper hud when you are near it, but every mission takes you into such locations that you have to leave it behind striping you out of these advantages.
The grappling hook is suddenly something you can only use in certain places when in previous titles it was one of the funniest things to use.

The guns feel horribly underpowered atleast the guns I have found so far and that's most of them. There is a crossbow that fires exploding arrows and you would obviously expect it to be powerful weapon to use considering that it has a 1 shot clip, but no. It's horribly underpowered and thus useless.
I found 3 different machineguns with one having a burst firemode, yet they all felt excatly the same and didn't seem to have any difference between damage either.
Add the underpowered guns with though, fast melee enemies that quickly swarm you and your ridiculously slow walking/sprinting speed the combat overall is quite horrible that only makes you want to quit playing games completely.

If someone came to me and told that this game is the first in the trilogy I would believe them considering how much they have removed and reduced compared to the previous games.

Overall if you want to play Lost Planet game you're better off buying the first or the second game depending on if you like Single- or Multiplayer more.
All this game makes me do is thinking that I really should dig out my Lost Planet 2 and play something that I can actually enjoy.
Also one small thing that REALLY bothers me to ridiculous degrees is the main character not having anykind of headgear to protect him from the cold that can freeze a human in seconds.
It's explained in the story, but it's still complete bulls**t. It's because he has technology installed into the collar of his suit.
Explanation that is on the same level as Magic, Nanomachines or Magical Nanomachines.

reviewText:
I've played the previous games in the series, and have enjoyed them.

When I found out they were making a 3rd one I was pretty excited. I didn't buy it day one though since I'm the type of person who waits for the price to drop. Needless to say I didn't read any reviews before picking this one up when it went on sale, and I'm glad I didn't because the game is nothing like many of the review say. It's an amazing experience and I loved it.

If I had known how much I would enjoy this I would've paid full price for it on release.

It took me about 10 hours to finish on medium difficulty, and I plan on going through it again on hard soon.

In this Lost Planet game you play as a man working for NEVEC away from his family on earth to support them. This game is before the events of Lost Planet 1 & 2 so it was before they started weaponizing their vehicles. This limitation didn't bother me since it fit the narrative, and I feel as though it was well executed. In any case I really enjoyed the story, and I hope they do a sequel to this game, but I can't count on it seeing how this one was received.

reviewText:
This looks like a nice game but it is a horrible, horrible port. The controlls are an absolute mess!
Be warned: the game cannot be played without a controller!!!
You can redefine your keys... or can you really? I mean I play with keyboard and the game lists R as the reload but the button does not work! Instead I had to press Shift-R to reload. I tried redefining reload to another key and then specifically back to R and now I was not able to reload the weapon at all. The defined R key would not work and neither would Shift-R. So I had to go back to the default configuration and after this I was afraid of changing anything else.
The game breaking bug however is very close to the start of the game. I was in the robo suit and had to close a valve. The game wrote on the screen that I had to rotate with WASD but nothing worked. Thankfully I have an XBox controller and tried using that. The game was saying that I just had to press the A button on the controller to rotate. Surprise! That did not work either... I finally managed to do it by rotating the left stick. This game port was clearly not tested with keyboard and mouse because the valve closing is a required checkpoint in the story line.
There are other control scheme oddities: you move with WASD and pick up items with P. Yep! you read it right P as in the complete opposite side of the keyboard from WASD.
I bought this game for 1 dollar together with 3 more games on Humble Bundle and I am not surprised that it got to such a price.
It is a shame because the game looks decent, cutscenes are nice and the characters are very well acted. Too bad they did not have a competent team working on the interface. I mean this is like having a Porche... that can only be driven using your teeth.
I only recommend this game at the price I bought it... maybe up to 3 EUR at most.

reviewText:
I have never played a Lost Planet¬Æ game before this one other than maybe a demo level for the first game on someone else's PC so I‚Äôm pretty new to the franchise.

TL:DR - If you have never played a Lost Planet¬Æ you should get / try this one, it will make you want to play the other ones.

Intro:

Keeping that in mind this is the perfect game to start out on. Supposedly this one has worse game play than the other two (probably because the game is more focused on telling its beautiful story) but it‚Äôs not terrible or unplayable or anything. This game is a prequel to Lost Planet 1 and sets up the game. It really gave me a feeling of wanting more when I finished the game.

Story:

The game's story is really polished. It does feel a bit rushed at the finale as everything gets really crazy and I do question the motives of characters. I think if the game had been longer and had more time it wouldn‚Äôt have been as harsh a transition but then a longer game would have made the story seem too drawn out. It‚Äôs a compromise and sadly it makes the ending feel rushed and not nearly as polished as the rest of the game.

Characters are good though sometimes they come off being a little robotic with animations and such. The game has a lot of colorful NPCs you can wander around and talk to or overhear throughout the game. Cut scenes are well done except for the moments where you have difficulty and die repeatedly having to watch one over and over again.

Game play:

The guns all feel same-y. The only real different one is the grenade launcher and that‚Äôs just because it shoots grenades. There are like 3 rifle / SMG weapons, 2 sniper rifles and a shotgun. The pistol is like a mix between the rifle and the sniper as it has slower fire but more accuracy. The game will recommend you use a certain type of weapon to beat certain types of enemies but it really doesn‚Äôt matter. Each gun roughly operates the same so its just a matter of finding which ones you like.

Each enemy is different but there are only like 12 types and that‚Äôs including bosses. You got swarmers, flyers, rollers, cat-like panthers, face-huggers and grenade like lobbing ones. They all kind of just swarm you. The game is like why make harder enemies when we can just make more?" and I get it
date:
it‚Äôs supposed to be an alien swarm attacking you but basically you just mow em all down. The panthers are the most strategy oriented.

The only enemy I didn‚Äôt list is these centipede crawlers that shoot bolts at you while others flank you. So you are forced to take cover but you can't because if you do another one comes and wrecks you.

Bosses are mostly lame. It‚Äôs basically a game of find out how to hit the glow-y spot enough. Most the time a new boss is fun but it‚Äôs when you fight it the 2nd or 3rd time that it gets old. Bosses are usually based on crabs and so it‚Äôs usually
recommended: dodge the pincer and shoot the arms and then the underbelly / back area.\n\nThe construction rig you get in the game is fun but it‚Äôs too slow. I‚Äôm pretty sure you can get out of it and run just as fast. It feels really tedious to walk from area to area in the game in this slow giant mech. The cool thing though is fighting bosses in the rig / giant construction mech. It makes a boss you have fought previously on the ground a whole lot more fun because you now get to fight a fair game size wise. Those pincers you had to shoot off before
hoursPlayed: now you can grab and just rip off like it was a real crab. It‚Äôs awesome.\n\nFinally
voteText:
the entire game you fight Akrid (the lost planet alien bug/plant life things) but in the endgame of Lost Planet 3 you finally get to shoot other humans. Sadly they often times do not shoot back. I found most weapons take them down in 1-3 hits which for machine guns is really easy. The snipers in the game make even faster work of human enemies as 90% of the time a sniper rifle can kill them before they even notice you. Often time‚Äôs enemies would spawn and I'd wipe them out before the elevator / drop ship even left.

Overall:

This game is good

reviewText:
I played with a controller and had a few problems with the controls. It was worth my time, but on a huge discount. I got it on humble bundle and it was worth it. I'd like to add that I've never played the first 2 Lost Planets.

Since the multiplayer looks interesting but is dead, the only attraction is the Solo campaign.I love the mood it makes; you feel like Jim would feel: a blue collar worker on a good day of work. You even have a music playlist in your rig! It's pretty sweet, you can probably check the soundtrack online.

To the story: the characters were interesting and not annoying, but the story is Avatar to a tee, except that the natives are japanese instead of native-americans.

The action is above lame most of the time, and then there is that one level that is way too difficult. It's a third person shooter that doesn't use cover often.

The segments in the mech suit are dragging for way too long, from the walking to the fighting.

I've seen some glitchy oddities, but very minor. Zero bugs to report from my part

reviewText:
Lost Planet 1 and 2 were decent, if completely forgettable shooters.

Lost Planet 3 is one of the worst games I have made the mistake of playing in recent memory.

In no particular order:

--The devs were so lazy that many of the in game prompts are wrong. I don't mean the game give controller prompts when you're using a keyboard and mouse. I mean that the on screen prompt actually tells you to press they completely wrong key.

--I have never seen such a bad autosave system in my life. Several times I loded my last save, only to discover four powerful enemies within five feet of me. Loading the save before, I was in the same situation. Luckily, you can load one of your manual saves. Just kidding! There are no manual saves, because this is an incredibly lazy console port.

--The lighting is all over the place. Buildings and caves are so dark that I frequently had to adjust my gamma up to see. Upon leaving the area, I had to adjust the gamma back down because the world was blindingly bright.

--Enemies are either so weak that using the handgun on them feels like overkill, or fast moving bullet sponges with powerful melee attacks. There is no middle ground.

--The game has a completely useless cover system. There is only one enemy I encountered that taking cover would have helped against. That enemy can just race around your cover and slash you, or simply lean over it and strangle you.

--Actually, I take it back. The cover is worse than useless. Half the time you just jump over it instead of sticking to it, leaving you out in the open in middle of a bunch of Akrid. If you do manage to stick to cover, rolling away from it to avoid melee attacks doesn't work half the time.

--The Utility Rig, which should be one of the highlights of the game, is a joke. Most of the time you only use it to slowly trudge from one place to the next. Sometimes it functions as a glorified fetch quest, demanding that you run around pushing buttons to open the path for it.

--When you finally do get to fight a giant monster with your rig, don't expect much. Giant Akrid fights are simply disguised QTEs. Tap a button to block, then tap another button to grab with your claw arm, then hold a third button to attack with your drill. Wait until the enemy attacks, then repeat. Giant robot combat has never been so boring.

--You do a lot of pointless running around. Run to the TEng post to harvest it. Run to the lab to turn in a quest. Run up a mountain hitting buttons for your rig. Seriously, if you were looking for a winter hike simulator, you found it.

--The characters. Oh, god, the characters. You play as Mr. Gruff Space Enginner Who Left His Wife And Child Behind So He Could Go Into Space To Support Them". Because

reviewText:
Such a great title for such a lazy game. To be honest, I haven't played any of the previous installments of LOST PLANET, but this here feels so bland, so generic. It's really like having a boring job where you don't have to think. Just do the same routine over and over again.
First of all, the LOST PLANET doesn't seem lost at all. What if certainly feels like is: extremely boring. In my five hours of playing, all I've experienced was: get an assignment, enter your rig, go somewhere, get attacked 2-3 times by the same half-dozen types of creatures, push some levers/retrieve some item, get attacked some more, go back, have coffee, etc.
Combat in this game is mainly dodge and shoot, dodge and shoot, repeat ad nauseum until all creature are dead. As I said, I've played this game for five hours, which is about four more than I mildly enjoyed it. I continued hoping that something would happen that broke the endless continuum I was stuck in, but nothing ever did. And don't even get me started about the rig and the bizarre catch-and-drill combat mechanics involved with it and the fact that it can't even take a few blows from a significantly smaller creature but will auto-repair in a minute under the condition that you exit it.

To sum it up: I've had significantly more fun at playing ALIENS:COLONIAL MARINES than at this game. It's a pity because the graphics are nice and the main character is quite likeable; not your run-of-the-mill supersoldier dude. But the game has no sense of exploration or alienation and at no moment did I feel lost. What the game certainly transmits is the feeling of being a blue collar at work, listening to a simple man's country songs on the radio of your truck... uh... rig and getting his job done so he can go home.

reviewText:
I finished Lost Planet 3 on hard difficulty settings in about 13.5 hours. Though I had some fun, there were also several reasons why I cannot recommend this game.

- You can't save the game yourself. Autosave is a nice feature, but if it is the only possibility it s*cks! You can only choose between the last checkpoint, the checkpoint before that and a new game.

- Cutscenes: I couldn't skip them. And it is annoying to see a scene for the 6th time, because the boss killed you.

- Interaction of badly placed checkpoints and cutscenes: some checkpoints are choosen very poorly! For example there was one in a cave, before a bossfight. Everytime a failed to kill the crab I had to walk trough a cavern, then enter the area where I had to place something, then I had to watch the cutscene and after I died I had to do this over and over again. Loading the checkpoint before that (in the attempt to switch my weapons) didn't work either, because it was only 30 seconds away.

- Bugs! There are severall bugs in this version. Starting with wrong instructions (press WASD to rotate, though you have to hit F), akrid spawning out of nowhere, akrid standing around without doing anywith, problems with taking cover and so on.

- Difficulty: except for some bossfights and very few situations the game is too easy, even on hard settings.

- Multiplayer: there is one, but nobody is playing it.

- The game ends with you having to press F very fast and very often. That's very lame.

Haven't played it too much at the time of writing this review, about 5 hours, but so far I can tell that it's an underrated gem. It's plenty of fun, cool environments, interesting setting and story, interesting character.
There are a couple things that annoy me, though. One of which is the lack of realism on several fronts, for one your mech (utility rig) which is a big ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• walking tank/bulldozer, can take less hits than you outside of it. That makes very little sense. Besides that, another weird unrealistic thing is that all characters have these fancy suits that protect them from all the cold and stuff but for some reason you never have any kind of headgear on. If this were real then your face would've been absolutely destroyed by frostbite and other hazards after half a mission. Seriously, at least give him some face coverage when he's outside in the cold wasteland.

I can see that it could get repetitive, but so far it isn't to me.
Really, though, that mech should be way stronger.
Another thing that kinda annoys me is some enemies that only have one or two weak spot(s), like just the mouth (and only when it is open) or just the tip of the tail, and it gets pretty hard to dodge some attacks and deal damage too. When they jump on you, you gotta play some kinda minigame with mashing the a button and then aiming your knife at their face, with the tigerlike akrids you only gotta do it three times but the weaker flying akrid takes way longer for some reason. Weird logic.

All in all my impression is quite positive thus far. I look forward to seeing what else the game has to offer.

reviewText:
The game is not amazing. In fact, I'd say most of the shooting is pretty subpar and boring the majority of the time, and the enemies are thrown at you over and over and over in terrible waves going from room to room. The core stuff is totally uninteresting.

Where the game is pretty cool is when it makes you feel like some future Canadian oil driller just trying to make it day to day. As you move from area to area you get to hear some future trucker country play on your radio. You start to get some nic nacs in your rig, and most of the characters you run into feel like a greater part of this independent drilling facility. The major problem is that the game never goes far enough in this direction, and later on most of these elements become shallow as it strips or waives your ability to participate in it, instead heavily focusing on funneling you down corridor after corridor and arena after arena of dull, uninspired combat.

You must know that you're making a bad game when you have the main character constantly complain about the level design, right? This is probably the reason Spark isn't doing so hot.

Don't get this game if you're a fan of the past games, but if you're interested in seeing the spark" of what could have been a comfy Canadian driller sim

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This is my first Lost Planet game

I like it.

Positive:
Storyline (so far) is simple, but it has me interested.
Combat is solid. (I love cover-based combat)
Weapons feel nice.
I was able to find a match in multiplayer.
Graphics are good, should age well.
Getting solid and stable FPS (GTX 970, FX-8350)

Neutral:
Linear missions.
Enemies are (so far) too easy.
For a cover-based shooter, there's a lot of concentration on standing in the open and dodging.

Negative:
vsync messes up FMV
Customize the soundtracks in your rig, awesome!... If you can get it to work :I
The controls are weird, but a few tweaks to the ini fixes that.
There's no option for borderless fullscreen, which is annoying, but tolerable.
The quick turn button is useless and awkward. It's faster and more natural to just move your mouse.
I wish there was a way to switch the camera between shoulders, that also makes it easier for level design, because they don't have to take into account that your left side is blind. (unless it's a horror game, in which that helps cause scares)
No co-op campaign.

reviewText:
Lost Planet 1 and 2 were decent, if completely forgettable shooters.

Lost Planet 3 is one of the worst games I have made the mistake of playing in recent memory.

In no particular order:

--The devs were so lazy that many of the in game prompts are wrong. I don't mean the game give controller prompts when you're using a keyboard and mouse. I mean that the on screen prompt actually tells you to press they completely wrong key.

--I have never seen such a bad autosave system in my life. Several times I loded my last save, only to discover four powerful enemies within five feet of me. Loading the save before, I was in the same situation. Luckily, you can load one of your manual saves. Just kidding! There are no manual saves, because this is an incredibly lazy console port.

--The lighting is all over the place. Buildings and caves are so dark that I frequently had to adjust my gamma up to see. Upon leaving the area, I had to adjust the gamma back down because the world was blindingly bright.

--Enemies are either so weak that using the handgun on them feels like overkill, or fast moving bullet sponges with powerful melee attacks. There is no middle ground.

--The game has a completely useless cover system. There is only one enemy I encountered that taking cover would have helped against. That enemy can just race around your cover and slash you, or simply lean over it and strangle you.

--Actually, I take it back. The cover is worse than useless. Half the time you just jump over it instead of sticking to it, leaving you out in the open in middle of a bunch of Akrid. If you do manage to stick to cover, rolling away from it to avoid melee attacks doesn't work half the time.

--The Utility Rig, which should be one of the highlights of the game, is a joke. Most of the time you only use it to slowly trudge from one place to the next. Sometimes it functions as a glorified fetch quest, demanding that you run around pushing buttons to open the path for it.

--When you finally do get to fight a giant monster with your rig, don't expect much. Giant Akrid fights are simply disguised QTEs. Tap a button to block, then tap another button to grab with your claw arm, then hold a third button to attack with your drill. Wait until the enemy attacks, then repeat. Giant robot combat has never been so boring.

--You do a lot of pointless running around. Run to the TEng post to harvest it. Run to the lab to turn in a quest. Run up a mountain hitting buttons for your rig. Seriously, if you were looking for a winter hike simulator, you found it.

--The characters. Oh, god, the characters. You play as Mr. Gruff Space Enginner Who Left His Wife And Child Behind So He Could Go Into Space To Support Them". Because

reviewText:
I wanted to like it.
There are some ideas that I really thought were good, such as having your own mech, upgrading it, and harvesting energy. I also didn't mind the slower pace of the game, and the concept of being a miner. The story started promising and I really enjoyed the characters and dialogue. I also really enjoyed gazing at the fantastic backgrounds as I walked through the snow in my mech.
Then the first couple of hours ended.
This game is nothing but padding and bad design decisions. The gunplay is nowhere near as satisfying as the previous entries and the Akrid are turned into generic melee, ranged, tank, and mini enemies. They're nowhere near as interesting or dynamic as the previous games, also dismemberment is missing unless you're fighting bosses. About the first 2 hours in you'll soon realize this game wastes your time. Combat is drawn out, and enemies are bullet sponges. Thankfully you can run past most enemies, unless it's a wave based section. The mech is wasted. Combat is stiff and telling the distance between enemies is infuriating, especially against smaller enemies, such as the wasp-like Akrid. Boss fights are nothing more than quick time events. Requiring no skill and lacking the experimentation that was present in the other games. There is also the forced slow walking, slow mech walking speed, and others to waste your time. Thanks to all of this the story loses focus, and I lost total interest in it later. Later conversations with characters‚Äô result in constant fetch quests, which brought constant groans and eye rolling from me.

The padding is so bad that I just can't even bring myself to finish the game. Avoid this one and buy Lost Planet 1 & 2 instead; they're FAR better games.

reviewText: Eh... having finally gotten to this game I was a little disappointed at how short it was. Didn't try the multiplayer aspect and I think it's safe to assume that it's dead. As closure for this series, I don't think this game really did it justice. The game itself wasn't bad, and I found myself eager to continue through but there was almost no incentive to complete side missions (like the DNA tracker) and the general lack of those available being interesting was enough reason to forget most of it. For instance, in the story you are required to setup a thermal post, and about 2-3 missions later a quest opens up for you to collect the energy (2500) which is a fair amount of currency. However, unless you are buying weapons/upgrades from the quartermaster there is little reason to do this. reviewText:
I have never played a Lost Planet¬Æ game before this one other than maybe a demo level for the first game on someone else's PC so I‚Äôm pretty new to the franchise.

TL:DR - If you have never played a Lost Planet¬Æ you should get / try this one, it will make you want to play the other ones.

Intro:

Keeping that in mind this is the perfect game to start out on. Supposedly this one has worse game play than the other two (probably because the game is more focused on telling its beautiful story) but it‚Äôs not terrible or unplayable or anything. This game is a prequel to Lost Planet 1 and sets up the game. It really gave me a feeling of wanting more when I finished the game.

Story:

The game's story is really polished. It does feel a bit rushed at the finale as everything gets really crazy and I do question the motives of characters. I think if the game had been longer and had more time it wouldn‚Äôt have been as harsh a transition but then a longer game would have made the story seem too drawn out. It‚Äôs a compromise and sadly it makes the ending feel rushed and not nearly as polished as the rest of the game.

Characters are good though sometimes they come off being a little robotic with animations and such. The game has a lot of colorful NPCs you can wander around and talk to or overhear throughout the game. Cut scenes are well done except for the moments where you have difficulty and die repeatedly having to watch one over and over again.

Game play:

The guns all feel same-y. The only real different one is the grenade launcher and that‚Äôs just because it shoots grenades. There are like 3 rifle / SMG weapons, 2 sniper rifles and a shotgun. The pistol is like a mix between the rifle and the sniper as it has slower fire but more accuracy. The game will recommend you use a certain type of weapon to beat certain types of enemies but it really doesn‚Äôt matter. Each gun roughly operates the same so its just a matter of finding which ones you like.

Each enemy is different but there are only like 12 types and that‚Äôs including bosses. You got swarmers, flyers, rollers, cat-like panthers, face-huggers and grenade like lobbing ones. They all kind of just swarm you. The game is like why make harder enemies when we can just make more?" and I get it
date:
it‚Äôs supposed to be an alien swarm attacking you but basically you just mow em all down. The panthers are the most strategy oriented.

The only enemy I didn‚Äôt list is these centipede crawlers that shoot bolts at you while others flank you. So you are forced to take cover but you can't because if you do another one comes and wrecks you.

Bosses are mostly lame. It‚Äôs basically a game of find out how to hit the glow-y spot enough. Most the time a new boss is fun but it‚Äôs when you fight it the 2nd or 3rd time that it gets old. Bosses are usually based on crabs and so it‚Äôs usually
recommended: dodge the pincer and shoot the arms and then the underbelly / back area.\n\nThe construction rig you get in the game is fun but it‚Äôs too slow. I‚Äôm pretty sure you can get out of it and run just as fast. It feels really tedious to walk from area to area in the game in this slow giant mech. The cool thing though is fighting bosses in the rig / giant construction mech. It makes a boss you have fought previously on the ground a whole lot more fun because you now get to fight a fair game size wise. Those pincers you had to shoot off before
hoursPlayed: now you can grab and just rip off like it was a real crab. It‚Äôs awesome.\n\nFinally
voteText:
the entire game you fight Akrid (the lost planet alien bug/plant life things) but in the endgame of Lost Planet 3 you finally get to shoot other humans. Sadly they often times do not shoot back. I found most weapons take them down in 1-3 hits which for machine guns is really easy. The snipers in the game make even faster work of human enemies as 90% of the time a sniper rifle can kill them before they even notice you. Often time‚Äôs enemies would spawn and I'd wipe them out before the elevator / drop ship even left.

Overall:

This game is good

reviewText:
Lost Planet 3 is a good game that gets completely ruined by an excessive amount of padding and uneven pacing. If this game had been cut down to 5 or 6 hours, it would have been great, unfortunately it's twice that length, meaning almost everything gets stretched beyond enjoyability. Everything gets repeated over and over again in an MMO like grind. You fight a boss once, you'll fight him two more times. You drill a well, you'll drill three more. You fix one broken switch, five more await. All while being forced to stagger in your helpless Mech from location to location in excruciatingly slow fashion because fast travel doesn't open up until you're a few hours into the game, and even then it only works half of the time. And that is the real shame of this game, it wastes your time to such an insane degree that it becomes almost insulting; why do I need to take three different elevators to visit the labs? And the worst part is that, in truth, none of it was needed. The story was great, until the bad ending, the mechanics and gameplay were varied and enjoyable, the devs didn't need to inflate the run time. Paired with its multiplayer component, a shorter campaign would have been fine. Instead you have three, maybe four hours worth of quality gameplay and two-ish hours of cutscenes, stretched out to span twelve or so hours. Resulting in what could have been an amazing game, being rendered a complete waste of time.

Here is my in-depth review
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CWu1PT-kHVk

reviewText:
This game honestly falls right down the middle of the mediocrity line.
In terms of story and atmosphere it does what it aims to do seamlessly with perfection; Jim Raynor..... I mean; Jim Peyton is your main character; with his mannerisms and look you'll be reminded of your average cowboy hero. Which the inclusion of the soundtrack in your rig helps even more to solidify that.
However; it goes without saying this game has some major issues, when you play Gears of Lost Planet 3; you'll notice that things like button prompts are faulty; even for the default button settings. Which is sad.
Another major issue is that near the end of the game; you stop doing the you vs. weird plant creatures. Instead it becomes a shooting gallery.
All in all; the game does some things well; atmosphere, story, the way it fleshes out characters. All very well done.
The actual game aspect of the game is a bit of a tragedy however; it treats you like an idiot, gives you the wrong prompts, and the mech battles themselves felt anything but satisfactory.

reviewText:
Very buggy controls. I spend the better part of 3 hours stuck between a set of crates, no way out. I reset the game, watched Youtube for help, nothing worked.  It has a few other places before that that where also a bit glitchy.  All in all it started out pretty good. The key mapping is screwed, you can't remap the keys and have them actuaully work, they reset back to default, sometimes, sometimes they map to whatever the hell they want and you have to try and find which key.

If it was fixed, it would be a great game, but the getting stuck glitch for hours really killed it for me .. i asked for a refund.

Oh ,, it also has a habit of resetting back to the start screen every 10 - 15 minutes with a sign in error or something. What sign in ? I had to use steam offline to get it to stop. Totally frustrating.

reviewText:
The definition of average. The shooting is average, the graphics are average. The weapon selection is average. Boss fights have an epic feel, but definitely not as epic as the first two in the series.

The story is extremely predictable, but still solid, and although they fit generic archetypes, they are all fleshed out well enough and pretty interesting.

There is honestly not much to say about the game. Its average, but engaging enough to see through the end. The story and characters are the best part. And the gameplay is serviceable enough to not get bored through at least one playthrough.

Buy it on sale. Under $10 or in a capcom bundle will do.

reviewText:
LP3 is a joke.
Clunky controls (a nightmare to map btw) and gameplay in general. It's also pretty ugly for a 2013 game, like Dead Space is very similar in desing as far as UI is concerned, LP3 does more or less the same things, but really bad. Like when you open the map for example, it's a holograph, but unlike dead space it's not in 3d, it's a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• overlay. There's also the same type of guiding system, but instead of the neat beam that lights the ground, it just markers, why bother when you have a minimap? Just make the minimap actually readable and you won't need that, just putting that out there. Same deal for graphics, it isn't really ugly, but it isn't 2008 either if you catch my meaning.
The worst of all must be the acting, sound desing and character desing. Can't think of a way to make the story and characters more clich√© for starters, take generic bad sci-fi trying to copy Alien 3 but swf, and put a Nicolas Cage twist to it. Like, make it as garbage and soulless as possible, and you have the setting for LP3. Hell, the hero even looks like Nic Cage. The voice acting is all over the place: the obnoxious french guy that they couldn't bother to get voiced by an actual french guy (just say ouiii and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• all the time, amiright?), the strong black that doesn't have any substance (just say hell no and such all the time, you'll be fine), the fat guy supervisor that no one really respects but he signs the paychecks so yeah (Alien 3 again), etc...
And the character design, just take ironic or exagerated cyber punk clothes in a serious context. Like take the armor in UT 2004, but in a serious sf setting with 2 deep 4 u plot, and there you have it.
And to top it off, it's a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• port, not even the cinematics look that good.

TLDR: It's trash and you're better off playing LP2. Oh wait, it's a bad port too. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Capcom / 20.

reviewText:
So, to get to the laboratory you have to:
- fast travel to the main hangar
- exit your rig
- get the nearest elevator, point it to the laboratory
- run along the hallway, reach the living quarters then go to the faaaarthest back
- get into another elevator
- again, run along the hallway, then descend with yet ANOTHER elevator
- run again, and enter the decontamination chamber
- wait nervously inside
- FINALLY, enter the laboratory and find that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Kovac at the end of the laboratory....................for the 1st half of the game

On the 2nd half of the game, that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• EVEN GO FURTHER inside

- from the 1st place you found him, enter YET ANOTHER decontamination chamber
- wait for that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• scanner to scan you with a pace slower than my grandma's walking
- enter the 2nd laboratory
- run again along the hallway, and finally found him near the console, manically scanning a dead Akrid
- talk to him to get sarcastic remarks for finishing his stupid errands

My fastest time to reach the 2nd laboratory is 1 minute and 53 seconds. And yes, I installed my game in my NVME SSD (cool huh?)

And yes, the travel back time to the hangar is more or less the same

So basically you're going to spend at least 4 minutes going back and forth, times how many errands you want to gladly run for him, just to hear his lovely sarcasm

10/10 would play this run-to-the-laboratory simulator again
